frameDefinitions: A Self_mover responds to a (real or imagined) danger by moving away from it.
A Self_mover leaves an initial Source location.
An Employee voluntarily leaves the service of an Employer.
A Self-moving Escapee departs from an Undesirable_location.
A Communicator conveys a Message to an Addressee; the Topic and Medium of the communication also may be expressed.
In this frame a Traveler goes on a journey, an activity, generally planned in advance, in which the Traveler moves from a Source location to a Goal along a Path or within an Area.
frameExamples: She had <t>fled</t> from DCS facilities several times before..
Leah <t>quit</t> her job after one month because of an evil force.
Let's hope it did n't have time to <t>communicate</t> any of its findings to its overlords.
Ellen <t>journeyed</t> to Europe with five suitcases.
listRoleDefinitions: <fen>Self_mover</fen> is the living (or self-directed) being which moves under its own power.
<fen>Source</fen> is used for any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion.
<fen>Path</fen> is used for any description of a trajectory of motion involving a landmark which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor a <fen>Goal</fen>.  This includes 'middle of path'' expressions.
<fen>Goal</fen> is used for any expression which tells where the <fen>Self_mover</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.
The direction that the <fen>Self_mover</fen> heads in during the motion.
The time when the motion occurs.

The <fen>Place</fen> is the location within which a defined motion takes place.  Any specified or implied  <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> should designate a location contained with the <fen>Place</fen>.
This is the entity which moves under its own power.

Any expression which implies a definite starting-point of motion expresses the frame element <fen>Source</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the prepositional object expresses the starting point of motion. In particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.
The time at which the motion takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the motion (which is specified by a <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) is located.
The person who is obligated to perform some task in order to receive compensation.
The person (or institution) in whose employ  the <fen>Employee</fen> stood.
The Field that one works in.
The label given to a particular type of service that the employer quits.
This role identifies the Time when an <fen>Employee</fen> quits the employment of the <fen>Employer</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Employee</fen> quits the employment of the <fen>Employer</fen>.
The <fen>Escapee</fen> manages to leave the <fen>Undesirable_location</fen>.
The <fex name='Undesirable_location'>Undesirable_location</fex> is where the Escapee begins.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the escaping occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the Escaping occurs.
The sentient entity that uses language in the written or spoken modality to convey a <fen>Message</fen> to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
<fen>Message</fen> is a proposition or set of propositions that the <fen>Communicator</fen> wants the <fen>Addressee</fen> to believe or take for granted.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about', but in some cases it can appear as a direct object.
The physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The time at which the communication takes place.
The location where the act of communication occurs.

This is the <fen>Area</fen> in which the traveling takes place. This frame element describes the enclosed area inside which travelling, of unspecified <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen> takes place.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is the location where the travelers end up.
The <fen>Path</fen> is the route along which the travel takes place.
This is the living being which travels. Normally, the <fen>Traveler</fen> is expressed as an external argument.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the starting point of the trip.

The <fen>Mode_of_transportation</fen> expresses how the motion of the <fen>Traveler</fen> is effected, by their body or by a vehicle which holds and conveys the <fen>Traveler</fen>. Vehicles can move in any way and in any medium. They are usually expressed obliquely with 'in' or 'by'.
The direction in which the <fen>Traveler</fen> goes.
When the traveling occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location of the motion. It describes the area in which motion (with a specified <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>) takes place.
listRoleExamples: He replaces Michael Lawrie, 50, who quit <fex>IBM</fex> to run Siebel.
Actually Iquit <fex>in the lobby</fex> before I got to my office.
<fex>He</fex> finds it hard to communicate with people, not least his separated parents .
How do you communicate to them <fex>that you really like them</fex> ?
Had someone communicated to the capital <fex>about the flagrant disregard of the religious law</fex> ?
Opinions are usually communicated <fex>over the telephone</fex> and are often given within 24 hours.
Barney used to travel <fex>by bus </fex> a lot
